quotations.title: Quotations from Neil Gaiman's The Sandman

quotation.p: Roderick Burgess's waking dreams are of the power and the glory. And of death, of course. Especially death.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #1: "Sleep of the Just"

quotation.p: Uh, Father, Magus. I've found something that may cast some light on our guest. In the Paginarum Fulvarum...
quotation.source: Alex Burgess, in SANDMAN #1: "Sleep of the Just"

quotation.p: It was a dark and stormy nightmare...
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #2: "Imperfect Hosts"

quotation.p: The process was slow at first, my lord. Things in the dreamworld began to transmute. I was aware of it in my library... Slowly, the words began to fade. Some time after you vanished, my books became bound volumes of blank paper. The next day the whole library was gone. I never found it again...
quotation.source: Lucien, in SANDMAN #2: "Imperfect Hosts"

quotation.p: "Atropos? No. Not now. You might as well call me the Morrigan!"
"She's right, my ducks. Might as well call us Tisiphone, Alecto, and Magaera -- and that takes us back, eh?"
"Might as well call us Diana, Mary, and Florence. Ha-ha! Uh, sorry."
quotation.source: The Three, in SANDMAN #2: "Imperfect Hosts"

quotation.p: Have you ever had one of those days when something just seems to be trying to tell you somebody?
quotation.source: John Constantine, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: "Hullo London."
"Hullo John Constantine."
"How are you then, London?"
"All right. Full of people. Raining. You?"
quotation.source: Constantine's internal dialogue, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: One thing I've learned. You can know anything. It's all there. You just have to find it.
quotation.source: John Constantine, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: When I got back she was gone along with me stereo, the telly, me Silver Surfers -- any old junk she could convert to money. And she'd long since converted the money into junk. Stupid bitch. Sometimes I still miss her.
quotation.source: John Constantine, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: It is never "only a dream", John Constantine. Here less than other places...
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: ... see the sun set in the hand of the man ...
quotation.source: Rachel, in SANDMAN #3: "Dream a Little Dream of Me"

quotation.p: I sprinkle sand into the waters of night. The grains burn as they fall, reminding me of another in times long passed away. I watched him even then as he fell, his face undefeated, his eyes still proud.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: It is time for me to walk the abyss. Time to reclaim my own. I must talk to the Morningstar. I do not have high hopes for the meeting.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: THere's one at the door, at the gate to damnation. Is it thief, thug or whore? There's one at the door, and there's room for one more till the end of Creation.
quotation.source: Squatterbloat, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: The wood of suicides has changed since my last visit to Hell. I remember it as a tiny grove. Now it resembles a forest.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: Never trust a demon. He has a hundred motives for anything he does... Ninety-nine of them, at least, are malevolent.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: One of you has my helm; my mask of pure dream. I crafted it myself, from the bones of a dead god.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #4: "A Hope in Hell"

quotation.p: I thank you, last Martian. If you wish, you may dream of the City of Focative Mirrors...
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #5: "Passengers"

quotation.p: Mother said, if you are going to be a criminal, John, you are not going to bring shame on the family name. I had to change it. I called myself Destiny. Dee is for destiny...
quotation.source: John Dee, in SANDMAN #5: "Passengers"

quotation.p: Dee is for lots of things. Death. Dust. Darkness. Demons.
quotation.source: John Dee, in SANDMAN #5: "Passengers"

quotation.p: All Bette's stories have happy endings. That's because she knows where to stop. She's realized the real problem with stories -- if you keep them going long enough, they always end in death.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #6: "24 Hours"

quotation.p: I will be a wise and tolerant monarch, dispensing justice fairly, and only setting nightmares to rip out the minds of the evil and wicked. Or just anybody I don't like.
quotation.source: John Dee, in SANDMAN #7: "Sound and Fury"

quotation.p: "It is a comfort in wretchedness to have companions in woe." (Marlowe. Faust.) Of course, he was talking about Hell. But it applies equally to Arkham.
quotation.source: Jonathan Crane, in SANDMAN #7: "Sound and Fury"

quotation.p: Oho, my sainted aunt, have I become a victim of brain fever, the curse of academia...?
quotation.source: Jonathan Crane, in SANDMAN #7: "Sound and Fury"

quotation.p: Looking back, the process of coming up with the Lord of Dreams seems less like an act of creation than one of sculpture: as if he were already waiting, grave and patient, inside a block of white marble, and all I needed to do was chip away everything that wasn't him.
quotation.source: From Neil Gaiman's afterword in the "Preludes and Nocturnes" TPB

quotation.p: We have seen stranger things in dreams; and fictions are merely frozen dreams, linked images with some semblance of structure. They are not to be trusted, no more than the people who create them.
quotation.source: From the introduction to the SANDMAN "The Doll's House" TPB

quotation.p: You are utterly the stupidest, most self-centered, appallingest excuse for an anthropomorphic personification in this or any other plane!
quotation.source: Death berates Dream, in SANDMAN #8: "The Sound of Her Wings"

quotation.p: There is another version of the tale. That is the tale the women tell each other, in their private language that the men-children are not taught, and that the old men are too wise to learn. And in that version of the tale perhaps things happened differently. But then, that is a women's tale, and it is never told to men.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #9: "Tales in the Sand"

quotation.p: You lot may die. I expect you will, 'cos you're stupid. Not me, though.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #13: "Men of Good Fortune"

quotation.p: And in the meantime, I've started in a trade. Working with a friend of mine. It won't last. But it's a new trade. It's called printing. Don't need to be a guild member -- not yet. Never be a real demand for it, mind you. Hard work.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #13: "Men of Good Fortune"

quotation.p: Her kind walk amidst the flotsam of lives they have sacrificed, for their own purposes, till friendless and alone they needs must make the final sacrifice.
quotation.source: Dream, on Lady Johanna Constantine, in SANDMAN #13: "Men of Good Fortune"

quotation.p: "Death's a capricious thing, innit?"
"Yes. Yes, she is."
quotation.source: Hob Gadling and Dream, in SANDMAN #13: "Men of Good Fortune"

quotation.p: I doubt I'm any wiser than I was five hundred years back. I'm older. I've been up, and been down, and been up again. Have I learned aught? I've learned from my mistakes, but I've had more time to commit more mistakes.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #13: "Men of Good Fortune"

quotation.p: "If I hear another of your theological paradoxes, I'll scream. Frankly, today I don't care if God exists or not."
"I doubt He feels likewise, Miss Walker."
quotation.source: Rose Walker and Gilbert, in SANDMAN #14: "Collectors"

quotation.p: "Surely, what the Choirboy is describing is a worst-case scenario, once they've caught you alive -- and you don't get the money, remember that."
"But, Carrion, we don't do it for the money!"
quotation.source: Two serial killers, in SANDMAN #14: "Collectors"

quotation.p: I tell you, I'm sick and tired of women in our line being stereotyped as black widows or killer nurses. I'm a serial killer, and a woman, and I'm proud of it.
quotation.source: Dog Soup, in SANDMAN #14: "Collectors"

quotation.p: And they left, slowly, one by one, with reluctance, leaving the safety of the light for the chill certainties of the darkness.
quotation.source: The convention breaks up, in SANDMAN #14: "Collectors"

quotation.p: It seemed like the night sucked them up, took them into its dark heart. It seemed like the darkness swallowed them... Perhaps it did.
quotation.source: The convention breaks up, in SANDMAN #14: "Collectors"

quotation.p: Zelda has a reassuring moral homily concerning God, difficult times, and a variable number of footprints in the sand. She told it to me once, and it cheered me up remarkably.
quotation.source: Chantal, in SANDMAN #15: "Into The Night"

quotation.p: "Do you know what Freud said about dreams of flying? It means you're really dreaming about having sex."
"Indeed? Tell me, then, what does it mean when you dream about having sex?"
quotation.source: Rose Walker and Dream, in SANDMAN #15: "Into The Night"

quotation.p: I left because I was curious. And because I was tired. Life as a human contains substance I never dreamed of in the Dreaming, Lord. The little victories, and the tiny defeats. I had my reasons.
quotation.source: Gilbert, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: "I do not understand--"
"Of course you don't. You're obviously not very bright, but I shouldn't let it bother you."
quotation.source: Dream and Unity Kinkaid, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: If my dream was true, then everything we know, everything we think we know is a lie.
quotation.source: From Rose Walker's diary, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: It means the world's about as solid and as reliable as a layer of scum on the top of a well of black water which goes down forever, and there are things in the depths that I don't even want to think about.
quotation.source: From Rose Walker's diary, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: It means that we're just dolls. We don't have a clue what's really going down, we just kid ourselves that we're in control of our lives while a paper's thickness away things that would drive us mad if we thought about them for too long play with us, and move us around from room to room, and put us away at night when they're tired, or bored.
quotation.source: From Rose Walker's diary, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: Dreams are weird and stupid and they scare me.
quotation.source: From Rose Walker's diary, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: "And then she woke up." I suppose there are worse endings.
quotation.source: From Rose Walker's diary, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: Desire, listen to me carefully. Remember this. We of the endless are the servants of the living -- we are not their masters. We exist because they know, deep in their hearts, that we exist.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: Human beings are the creatures of desire. They twist and bend as I require it. If I thought otherwise, I would crack, like Delirium; or I would abandon my realm, like our lost brother.
quotation.source: Desire's thoughts, in SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: And Desire walks the endless pathways of its body, certain that he, or she, or it, is in sole and only control of its destiny. The only inhabitant of the twilight realm of Desire; and it feels nothing like a doll. Nothing like a doll at all.
quotation.source: Closing words of SANDMAN #16: "Lost Hearts"

quotation.p: The paths fork and divide. With each step you take through Destiny's garden, you make a choice; and every choice determines future paths. However, at the end of a lifetime of walking you might look back, and see only one path stretching out behind you; or look ahead, and see only darkness.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: The garden of Destiny. You would know it if you saw it. After all, you will wander it until you die. Or beyond. For the paths are long, and even in death there is no ending to them.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: A family meeting, eh, Destiny? You haven't redecorated in the last 300 years, I see. Oh well. And still wearing basic grey...
quotation.source: Desire, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: I lost some time once. It's always in the last place you look for it.
quotation.source: Delirium, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Oh, just shut up and let me finish. You can shout at me afterwards.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Desire smells almost subliminally of summer peaches, and casts two shadows: one black and sharp-edged, the other translucent and forever wavering, like heat haze.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Desire smiles in brief flashes, like sunlight glinting from a knife-edge. And there is much else that is knife-like about Desire.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Never a possession, always the possessor, with skin as pale as smoke, and eyes tawny and sharp as yellow wine: Desire is everything you have ever wanted. Whoever you are. Whatever you are. Everything.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Despair says little, and is patient.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Despair, Desire's sister and twin, is queen of her own bleak bourne. It is said that scattered through Despair's domain are a multitude of tiny windows, hanging in the void. Each window looks out onto a different scene, being, in our world, a mirror. Sometimes you will look into a mirror and feel the eyes of Despair upon you, feel her hook catch and snag on your heart.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Destiny is the oldest of the Endless; in the beginning was the Word, and it was traced by hand on the first page of his book, before ever it was spoken aloud.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Destiny smells of dust and the libraries of night. He leaves no footprints. He casts no shadow.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: For Delirium was once Delight. And although that was long ago now, even today her eyes are badly matched; one eye is a vivid emerald green, spattered with silver flecks that move; her other eye is vein blue. Who knows what Delirium sees, through her mismatched eyes?
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: Dream casts a human shadow, when it occurs to him to do so.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 0

quotation.p: "Well, at least you've got the element of surprise on your side."
"That would not be honorable, Matthew. I have already sent a messenger to the Lord of Hell, to let him know that I will be coming. One must do these things properly."
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: They also held that the way to salvation was to give way to lust and temptation in all things. And no greater percentage of them turned up here than of any other religion. Amusing, isn't it?
quotation.source: Lucifer, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: I move from dreamer to dreamer, from dream to dream, hunting for what I need. Slipping and sliding and flickering through dreams; and the dreamers will wake and wonder why this dream seemed different, wonder how real their lives can truly be.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: I'm sorry, Your Majesty. The bastard hard disk's crashed again, but this hardware's still better than Roger Bacon's mechanical head.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling dreams of Queen Elizabeth I, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: "What's the occasion? Is it your birthday?"
"You must be born, to have a birthday."
quotation.source: Hob Gadling and Dream, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: They believe themselves Lucifer's equals, Cain, all these pitiful little gnats. But there is only one that we have ever owned to be our superior. There is but one greater than us, and to him... to him we no longer speak.
quotation.source: Lucifer, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: We do what we must, Lucien. Sometimes we can choose the path we follow. Sometimes our choices are made for us. And sometimes we have no choice at all.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: "Season of Mists", episode 1

quotation.p: Neil Gaiman, writer: To set certain popular misconceptions to rest once and for all:
1) He was not found wandering the sewers of London as a child during the winter of 1864, unable to say anything more than "Powerful big rats, gentlemen."
quotation.source: From the biographies in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: Neil Gaiman, writer: To set certain popular misconceptions to rest once and for all:
4) He did indeed have what most people would commonly understand as "eyes".
quotation.source: From the biographies in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: There is quite obviously no "underground kingdom beneath London inhabited by huge, intelligent rodents". And even if there were, any suggestion of Neil's involvement in the mazy territorial negotiations between Londons Above and Below can be considered a joke, and in poor taste at that.
quotation.source: From Neil Gaiman's biography in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: The details of his black life and dubious death are written in certain books, and the foolish and the curious may seek them out. Nothing could induce us to elaborate here; by comparision Gilles de Rais was an angel in human form, and de Sade a weak and simpering child. The world is well rid of him -- if rid of him it truly is.
quotation.source: P. Craig Russell's biography in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: They say she done them all of them in. They say she done it with an axe.
quotation.source: Karen Berger's biography in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: According to an old New York folk-tale, Alisa Kwitney appears in a bathroom mirror to people in the final stages of delirium tremens, and pleads with them to mend their ways. In another version of the same story she can be induced (by threatening to break the mirror) to reveal winning lottery ticket numbers.
quotation.source: Alisa Kwitney's biography in the SANDMAN "Season of Mists" TPB

quotation.p: The fraternity of critics, in reality a dark brethren, linked by profane rites and blood vows. To destroy an author they sacrifice a child and perform a critical mass...
quotation.source: Ideas crowd upon Richard Madoc, in SANDMAN #17: "Calliope"

quotation.p: A city in which the streets are paved with time. A train full of silent women, plowing forever through the twilight. Heads made of light. A small piece of blue cardboard. A plum, sweet and tart and cold. A were-goldfish who transforms into a wolf at full moon.
quotation.source: Ideas crowd upon Richard Madoc, in SANDMAN #17: "Calliope"

quotation.p: Two old women taking a weasel on holiday. Gryphons shouldn't marry. Vampires don't dance. A man who inherits a library card to the library in Alexandria. A rose bush, a nightingale, and a black rubber dog-collar.
quotation.source: Ideas crowd upon Richard Madoc, in SANDMAN #17: "Calliope"

quotation.p: I prayed to the darkness, to the night, to the carrion kind. I prayed to the king of the cats, the kind's emissary on Earth, he who walks amongst us and we do not know him. I prayed and I dreamed.
quotation.source: The visionary cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: "Justice?" It repeated. "Justice is a delusion you will not find on this or any other sphere. And wisdom? Wisdom is no part of dreams, lithe walker, though dreams are a part of the sum of each life's experiences, which is the only wisdom that matters. But revelation? That is the province of dream."
quotation.source: The skeleton bird, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: All cats can see futures, and see echoes of the past. We can watch the passage of creatures from the infinity of now, from all the worlds like ours, only fractionally different. And we follow them with our eyes, ghost things, and the humans see nothing.
quotation.source: The visionary cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: They dreamed the world so it always was the way it is now, little one. There never was a world of high cat-ladies and cat-lords.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: Then a human arose amongst them. A golden-furred male, bred and raised in the pleasure gardens of one of the sybaritic feline ladies.
quotation.source: The visionary cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: But if enough of us dream, if a bare thousand of us dream, we can change the world. We can dream it anew! A world in which no cat suffers from the malice of humans. In which no cats are killed by human caprice. A world that we rule.
quotation.source: The visionary cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: Dream the world. Not this pallid shadow of reality. Dream the world the way it truly is. A world in which all cats are queens and kings of creation. That is my message. And I shall keep moving, keep repeating it, until I die. Or until a thousand cats hear my words, and believe them, and dream, and we come again to paradise.
quotation.source: The visionary cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: Little one, I would like to see anyone -- prophet, king or God -- persuade a thousand cats to do anything at the same time.
quotation.source: The cynical cat, in SANDMAN #18: "A Dream of a Thousand Cats"

quotation.p: "So... we are here on your command, my lord, on Midsummer's Eve, by the Long Man of Wilmington. An odd choice of a place for us to perform..."
"Odd? Wendel's Mound was a theatre before your race came to this island."
"Before the Normans?"
"Before the humans."
quotation.source: Shakespeare and Dream, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: It is a fool's prerogative to utter truths that no one else will speak.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: "Thou speak'st aright: I am that merry wanderer of the night."
"'I am that merry wanderer of the night.'? I am that giggling - dangerous - totally - bloody - psychotic - menace - to - life-and-limb, more like it."
quotation.source: An actor and an audience member, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: Besides -- if you ask me, none of those women are women at all. They're males. I can tell. Human males taste more like rabbit than the females -- and they stick in your teeth. Oh yes.
quotation.source: Skarrow, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: You played me well, mortal. But I have played me for time out of mind. And I do Robin Goodfellow better than anyone.
quotation.source: Robin Goodfellow, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: "Not even Kit Marlowe will be able to gainsay that."
"You have not heard? Marlowe is dead, Will. He died in Deptford, three weeks back, of a knife wound to the head."
quotation.source: Shakespeare and Dream, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: Things have changed, and will change more; and Gaia no longer welcomes us as once she did.
quotation.source: Auberon, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: During your stay on this Earth the faerie have afforded me much diversion, and entertainment. Now you have left for your own haunts. And I would repay you all for the amusement. And more. They shall not forget you. That was important to me: that King Auberon and Queen Titania will be remembered by mortals, until this age is gone.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: Things need not have happened to be true. Tales and dreams are the shadow-truths that will endure when mere facts are dust and ashes, and forgot.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #19: "A Midsummer Night's Dream"

quotation.p: They say that cigarettes will kill you, eventually. Fine. That's just fine. I only wish they'd do it faster.
quotation.source: Element Girl, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: I like smoking cigarettes. It's something normal people do. I smoke a cigarette, and pretend I'm normal. And I wish I was dead.
quotation.source: Element Girl, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: "And you've come for me? Blessed, merciful death. You've come to make it all stop?"

"No. I haven't come for you, Rainie. There was a woman upstairs, changing the light bulb in her kid's room. The stepladder slipped... Like I said, I was passing and I heard you crying, and, well, the door was open..."
quotation.source: Element Girl and Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: Anyway: I'm not blessed or merciful. I'm just me. I've got a job to do and I do it. Listen: even as we're talking, I'm there for old and young, innocent and guilty, those who die together and those who die alone. I'm in cars and boats and planes, in hospitals and forests and abattoirs. For some folks death is a release and for others death is an abomination, a terrible thing. But in the end, I'm there for all of them.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: When the first living thing existed, I was there, waiting. When the last living thing dies, my job is finished. I'll put the chairs on tables, turn out the lights and lock the universe behind me when I leave.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: Rainie, mythologies take longer to die than people believe. They linger on in a kind of dream country that affects all of you.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: It's his never-ending battle against Apep, the serpent that never dies. Dumb. I told him, "The serpent that never dies is dead. I took her three thousand years ago! The never-ending battle ended..."
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: No, Mister Mulligan. I really can't get a message to her. I'm sorry. Who am I? Just a friend. Sometimes. Maybe. Sorry I couldn't help any. Be seeing you...
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #20: "Façade"

quotation.p: I'm going stir-crazy, and I've joined the ranks of the walking brain-dead, but otherwise I'm just peachy.
quotation.source: Lyta Hall on parenthood, in SANDMAN #40: "Parliament of Rooks"

quotation.p: "Hi Gregory. How they hanging?"
"UWURRRK."
"Yeah? You should try being a bird sometime."
quotation.source: Matthew the Raven and Gregory the Gargoyle, in SANDMAN #40: "Parliament of Rooks"

quotation.p: It is sometimes a mistake to climb, it is always a mistake never even to make the attempt.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: "Fear of Falling"

quotation.p: "I hesitate to tell you this, Sam, but there are certain individuals who have accused me of. Mm. Well, being mad."
"You shock me, Your Majesty."
quotation.source: Norton I, Emperor of the United States, and Samuel Langhorne Clemens, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: "I am pleased to see that you are healthy."
"Healthy? I'm dead, Norton. You ever swallowed aconite? You don't get up and walk away again."
quotation.source: Norton I, Emperor of the United States, and the King of Pain in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: I am the Emperor of the United States, Pain. I am content to be what I am. What more than that could any man desire?
quotation.source: Norton I, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: "Desire? You disappoint me. This evening's display: bringing back a dead man to offer Norton the pleasures of the world. It was not very subtle."
"Go screw yourself, big brother."
quotation.source: Dream and Desire, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: I'll bring the Kindly Ones down on his blasted head.
quotation.source: Desire, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: They say that the world rests on the backs of 36 living saints - 36 unselfish men and women. Because of them the world continues to exist. They are the secret kings and queens of this world.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: I've met a lot of kings, and emperors and heads of state in my time, Joshua. I've met them all. And you know something? I think I liked you best.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: It's a great hat. Can I try it on?
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: "I must confess, I have always wondered what lay beyond life, my dear."
"Yeah, everybody wonders. And sooner or later everybody gets to find out."
quotation.source: Norton I and Death, in SANDMAN #31: "Three Septembers and a January"

quotation.p: Aye, Master Orpheus. Well, they do say that two heads are better than one.
quotation.source: Lady Johanna Constantine, in SANDMAN #29: "Thermidor"

quotation.p: "Will you kill all the poets, then, St. Just? Will you kill all the dreamers?"
"When they have served their purpose, yes. Fabre D'Eglantine devised our calendar, and he died with Danton last Germinal."
quotation.source: Lady Johanna Constantine and St. Just, in SANDMAN #29: "Thermidor"

quotation.p: [Thomas] Paine is useful as a rabble-rouser; but rabble-rousers are needed before revolutions, not after.
quotation.source: St. Just, in SANDMAN #29: "Thermidor"

quotation.p: Your son's head is valuable to you, and I am attached to mine. Indeed, hitherto we have been inseparable.
quotation.source: Lady Johanna Constantine, in SANDMAN #29: "Thermidor"

quotation.p: And from that Time on, the Song of Orpheus has always hovered at the Edge of my Perception; a Melody I can never fully recover, try howsoever I will. And do not doubt that there are many in Authority to whom I would sing it, if 'twere within my Power.
quotation.source: Lady Johanna Constantine, in SANDMAN #29: "Thermidor"

quotation.p: And I suppose if everybody cut off their heads and stuffed asafoetida into their mouths and buried their hearts at crossroads, then you'd do it too?
quotation.source: The grandfather in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: "Trees there were, old as trees can be, huge and grasping with hearts black as sin. Strange trees that some said walked in the night --"
"Okay. It was a forest. It had trees in it. I'm not stupid. I got it."
quotation.source: Grandfather and granddaughter in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: The young man's mother had died bringing him into the world; she gave him life, a small wooden finger-ring, and the name Vassily. There have been worse legacies.
quotation.source: The grandfather's tale in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: "A small bone that he had what?"
"Carved into the shape of a small bone."
"But it was a small bone already."
"He carved it into the shape of a different small bone. All right?"
quotation.source: Grandfather and granddaughter in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: "Of course you don't believe in fairies. You're fifteen. You think I believed in fairies at fifteen? Took me until I was at least a hundred and forty. Hundred and fifty, maybe. Anyway, he wasn't a fairy. He was a librarian. All right?"
"Mm. It all sounds suspiciously post-modern to me, Grandpa. Are you sure this is really a story from the old country?"
quotation.source: Grandfather and granddaughter in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: Listen, blood of my blood, although I'm a hard man to anger, and I love you deeply, if you interrupt me again so help me I'll rip out your throat with my teeth.
quotation.source: The grandfather gets annoyed in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: You shouldn't trust the story-teller; only trust the story.
quotation.source: The grandfather in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: In the black shadow of the Baba Yaga babies screamed and mothers miscarried; milk soured and men went mad.
quotation.source: In SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: Do you know how long it's been since I mislaid a book? Well, let's just say the continents weren't in their current shapes, not that that means anything to you.
quotation.source: Lucien in SANDMAN #38: "The Hunt"

quotation.p: Actors... I don't like actors. It's a profession based on lies and disrespect. Pretending to be what you are not.
quotation.source: The emperor Augustus in SANDMAN #30: "August"

quotation.p: It will be good to be dead - to be a god.
quotation.source: The emperor Augustus in SANDMAN #30: "August"

quotation.p: We write our names in the sand, and then the waves roll in and wash them away.
quotation.source: The emperor Augustus in SANDMAN #30: "August"

quotation.p: "There's a few thousand square miles of central Australia, a couple of Pacific islands, a field in Ireland, an occasional mountain in Arizona..."
"An occasional mountain?"
"It's not a very big mountain, but it's only there occasionally."
quotation.source: Fiddler's Green and Rustichello, in SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: "You look terrible. White as the man in the moon. Are you always so pale?"
"That depends on who's watching."
quotation.source: Marco Polo and Dream, in SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: And forewarned is seldom forearmed. Not even in the shifting zones.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: He found himself able to see each falling grain, distinct and unique; and he knew then he was dreaming.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: There are really patterns. It was a revelation, of a kind. Dreams and sand and stories. Deserts and cities and time.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: The grains fell slowly, tumbling down from the dream-king's pale fingers into his own travel-stained hands.
The patterns they formed as they fell illuminated his mind: a landscape strobed by flashes of distant lightning.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #39: "Soft Places"

quotation.p: You are mortal: it is the mortal way. You attend the funeral, you bid the dead farewell. You grieve. Then you continue with your life.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: And at times the fact of her absence will hit you like a blow to the chest, and you will weep. But this will happen less and less as time goes on.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: She has lots of things, although she seldom has much use for them. You should see her floppy hat collection.
quotation.source: Destruction talks about Death in SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: And Herakles was full of it. He just got dead drunk for a couple of weeks in Phrygia and told everyone he'd been to the land of the dead.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: "I thought you could foretell the future?"
"I don't need to know the future. When the future's over, then it's me..."
quotation.source: Orpheus and Death, in SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: "Mortal man?"
"Yes?"
"Beware of the dog."
quotation.source: Charon warns Orpheus, in SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: Thou hast made the Furies cry, Orpheus. They will never forgive you for that.
quotation.source: Queen Persephone, in SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: Orpheus watched through tear-stung eyes until he was out of sight. His father never even tried to look back.
quotation.source: The final line of SANDMAN: "The Song of Orpheus"

quotation.p: And there was also in that room the Other Egg of the Phoenix. (For the Phoenix when its time comes to die lays two eggs, one black, one white: From the white egg hatches the Phoenix-bird itself, when its time is come, but what hatches from the black egg no one knows.)
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #50: "Ramadan"

quotation.p: There were paths through the palace that none but Haroun Al Raschid knew; and this was because those who had drawn up the plans, and those who had built the paths, had all long since gone to their final reward: for it is seldom healthy to know the secrets of a king.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #50: "Ramadan"

quotation.p: Imagine a thousand thousand fireflies of every shape and color; Oh, that was Baghdad at night in those days.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #50: "Ramadan"

quotation.p: You have called me here, Haroun. It is unwise to summon what you cannot dismiss.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #50: "Ramadan"

quotation.p: And he prays as he walks (cursing his one weak leg the while), prays to Allah (who made all things) that somewhere, in the darkness of dreams, abides the other Baghdad (that can never die), and the other egg of the Phoenix. But Allah alone knows all.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #50: "Ramadan"

quotation.p: Dave McKean: Buy him a Margarita and he'll tell you why cats smile.
quotation.source: From the biographies in the SANDMAN "Fables and Reflections" TPB

quotation.p: "I look a mess."
"You're talking. With those cheekbones? I'd kill for those cheekbones. Mm. Well, maim, maybe."
quotation.source: Barbie and Wanda, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: Interesting. Great winds are coming, Matthew, and darkness, and much pain. Do you see? One of the skerries is dying... I fear only grief can be the outcome.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: "Don't you just love the subway? I just have to set foot on a subway train, and it's like a magic carpet, y'know? It could take you anywhere."
"Yeah, that's what I'm afraid of."
quotation.source: Wanda and Barbie, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: This is a bright place, filled with frightened people, and fast hard things that hurt and wound. No matter. I swore I would remain by her side forever, and until death divided us. I must walk until once more we are reunited.
quotation.source: Martin Tenbones, lost in New York, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: My death hovers near me, screeching and fluttering and giggling: a ghost death, in a ghost world. I tell myself I feel only ghost pain, and I will not let it hurt me.
quotation.source: Martin Tenbones, lost in New York, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: I am not afraid. O Princess Barbara, protect me now as I have protected you in days long past. O Murphy watch over me. I will not be afraid.
quotation.source: Martin Tenbones, lost in New York, in SANDMAN #32: "Slaughter on Fifth Avenue"

quotation.p: The present I won with my ticket is in the box. I go to open it. The baby smells of formaldehyde, not unpleasant. It is cold and slightly clammy to the touch. The autopsy scar is sewn together with black thread. It has been dead exactly seventy years.
quotation.source: Hazel dreams, in SANDMAN #33: "Lullabies of Broadway"

quotation.p: "Wanda?"
"Yeah?"
"You've got a thingie."
"Hazel, didn't anyone ever tell you that it's not polite to draw attention to a lady's shortcomings?"
quotation.source: Hazel and Wanda, in SANDMAN #34: "Bad Moon Rising"

quotation.p: You see, there are two ways into another's dreams. We can go through the dream king; or we can go by the moon's road. But the dream king has little time for you women, and even less for my kind; while the moon is ever ours. It's time to draw down the moon.
quotation.source: Thessaly, in SANDMAN #34: "Bad Moon Rising"

quotation.p: Where others ask timorously, Thessalian, your kind commanded, directed, ordered. It galled us. But the others are dust now, and less than dust. And one day you, in your turn, will join them. And then our compact will be over, and you will be ours, as they are.
quotation.source: The moon, in SANDMAN #34: "Bad Moon Rising"

quotation.p: It's like we fell down the rabbit hole, woke up in ... I don't know. Stephen King's basement.
quotation.source: Wanda, in SANDMAN #34: "Bad Moon Rising"

quotation.p: ... and there's no love lost between the trees and the Cuckoo. Not that they're on our side, mind you, although most of the trees are all right. Keep themselves to themselves, unless they're bothered, and only an idiot bothers a tree.
quotation.source: Wilkinson, in SANDMAN #35: "Beginning to See the Light"

quotation.p: "I remember the Hieromancer. I met him, when I was here before. He was a sweet old guy. Kind of like my grandfather. What happened to him?"
"He's dead. I expect that he's dead. If he's lucky he's dead."
quotation.source: Barbie and Wilkinson, in SANDMAN #35: "Beginning to See the Light"

quotation.p: I've been doing a lot of face-painting recently. Originally I was going to get a tattoo, but I don't want anything permanent anymore. It's like I can be a different person every day.
quotation.source: Barbie, in SANDMAN #35: "Beginning to See the Light"

quotation.p: "Wilkinson? What's the Hierogram?"
"It's um. Well, it's um. It's sort of more like an um. Well..."
quotation.source: Barbie and Wilkinson, in SANDMAN #35: "Beginning to See the Light"

quotation.p: I was one of seventeen children. We were all named Wilkinson -- I suppose it was roughest on the girls, but we all got used to it in the end. I blame the parents, really. ... It was just when they found a name they liked, they stuck with it.
quotation.source: Wilkinson, in SANDMAN #35: "Beginning to See the Light"

quotation.p: "And what's your name, caller?"
"Jim. Jim Morrison. Not the famous one."
"Hey, wouldn't that be a coup for my show if you were?"
quotation.source: New York talk radio, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: All sense of where I am, of who I am and where I'm going, has been swallowed by the dark. And I walk through the stars and sky, a trinity of dreams beneath the moon.
quotation.source: Walking the moon's road, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: Poor dead Luz, my little Judas. I could not find it in my heart to blame her: I, too, had been one of the servants of the Cuckoo, felt the overpowering need to protect and nurture her; to do anything that would make her happy. Luz got up. She stumbled. And then she walked into the blackness of his robe and she was gone. Murphy's peace be with you, Luz, if he has peace to give.
quotation.source: Dream uncreates the Land, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: There were giants and centaurs and witches and fauns; bears and trolls; even a handful of giant spiders. I saw Wilkinson and Prinado, walking together. They waved when they saw me. They walked past me, the living and the dead, and one by one they vanished into the darkness of his cloak.
quotation.source: Dream uncreates the Land, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: And then he reached out his hand and picked up the Land. I don't know how... It was like a little jewelled world. It didn't matter that it was tiny -- if it was tiny. I could see every waterfall and stream, every leaf on every tree. I could see everything.
quotation.source: Dream uncreates the Land, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: And then it crumbled in his hand. It was just dust, sand, a glittering multicolored sand that fell away into the chilly wind at the end of the world.
quotation.source: Dream uncreates the Land, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: "That's kind of my uh sort of a joke."
"That's right, George. It differs from the usual kind of joke only in the vast gulf between it and any kind of a sense of humor."
quotation.source: George's face and Wanda, in SANDMAN #36: "Over the Sea to Sky"

quotation.p: "You missed the open coffin at his folks' place -- Alvin looked pretty good, after the morticians were through with him. They cut his hair and put him in a suit and everything."
"But... Wanda was always so proud of her hair..."
quotation.source: Wanda's aunt and Barbie, in SANDMAN #37: "I Woke Up and One of Us Was Crying"

quotation.p: The service drones to its end. I realize that I'm already beginning to forget what Wanda looked like. Is identity that fragile? The thought scares me.
quotation.source: Barbie, in SANDMAN #37: "I Woke Up and One of Us Was Crying"

quotation.p: I never knew that places around here had such beautiful names. ... Cloverdale, Florissant, Mulberry Grove, Boonville, Salina, Aurora and Goodland. They sound like the names of magic kingdoms, don't they?
quotation.source: Barbie, in SANDMAN #37: "I Woke Up and One of Us Was Crying"

quotation.p: And if there's a moral there, I don't know what it is, save maybe that we should take our goodbyes whenever we can.
quotation.source: Barbie, in SANDMAN #37: "I Woke Up and One of Us Was Crying"

quotation.p: I spent more than half a year with Barbie and Wanda and Hazel and Foxglove and Wilkinson and Thessaly and the rest of them wandering around in my head. Some nights I still miss them.
quotation.source: From Neil Gaiman's afterword in the SANDMAN "A Game of You" TPB.

quotation.p: Neil Gaiman's favorite toys were mostly books. His favorite game was to find somewhere inaccessible and out of the way, and go read there for hours. He knew that he could go to Narnia or Oz or Cimmeria or New York if he just said the right thing or rubbed the right magic charm, but it just never happened.
quotation.source: Neil Gaiman's biography, in the SANDMAN "A Game of You" TPB.

quotation.p: Dave McKean's favorite toy was a wooden fish. It was called Fish. These days his favorite game is trying to get color copiers to do things they were never intended for, nor ever dreamed of doing.
quotation.source: Dave McKean's biography, in the SANDMAN "A Game of You" TPB.

quotation.p: Colleen Doran lived on a corner known as Crash Corner; one day she saw a child on a bicycle get hit by a car and fly 20 feet through the air. She was sitting in a tree in the front yard at the time. Her favorite book was The Secret Garden by Frances Hodgson Burnett.
quotation.source: Colleen Doran's biography, in the SANDMAN "A Game of You" TPB.

quotation.p: "She was a remarkable woman."
"All women are remarkable."
quotation.source: Orpheus and Andros, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: Blossom for a lady -- Rain in the doorway -- Not her sister -- Want/not want -- The views from the backs of mirrors -- Journal of the plague year -- "The number you have dialled..."
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: Change. Change. Change. Change... Change. Change. Chaaange. When you say words a lot they don't mean anything. Or maybe they don't mean anything anyway, and we just think they do.
quotation.source: Delirium, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: She'll phone you up, and hang around your house. When you ask her to leave you alone she'll just cry and not say anything -- look at you with hurt eyes and follow you around. Eventually this will make you so angry you'll find yourself needing desperately to make her say something. To make her react. To hurt her. To get her eyes out of your mind. After that it will be just a matter of time.
quotation.source: Desire to an unnamed partygoer, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: Delirium has, from time to time, visited Despair's grey realm. It is the antithesis of her own churning domain: formless and silent and still. Apathy hangs like damp mist in the chill air.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: Today he's sitting in their family room. Realizing that his life is over, wondering if he has the courage to physically end it. He doesn't. Isn't it beautiful?
quotation.source: Despair, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: In her world there are so many windows. Each opening shows her an existence that's fallen to her -- some only for moments, others for lifetimes.
quotation.source: Despair's realm, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: On the empty street, a corpse lay, waiting for the cart to take it to the plague pit; next to it lay a poor piper, untouched by disease, but dead drunk. He would come to his senses in the early hours of the following morning, in the plague pit, with soft earth on his face, and cold flesh beneath him, and believe himself in hell...
quotation.source: The London plague of 1665, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: "Let me observe here," said Defoe, writing somewhat after the event, "... The people were brought into a condition to despair of life." When Despair read that, through a mirror, she nodded with the satisfaction of one who had performed her duty with diligence and care.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: "Some things are changeless. People love, and die, they dream, destroy, despair, go mad. They fulfill their destinies, live out the course of their lives. We fulfill our function, as they fulfill theirs... That will not change."
"You think not?"
quotation.source: Despair and Destruction, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: You know how she is when she gets an idea into her head. I mean, when one finally penetrates.
quotation.source: Desire describes Delirium, in SANDMAN #41: "Brief Lives:1"

quotation.p: It always rains on the unloved -- Wet dreams -- A fishing expedition -- She kisses wyverns (The Disneyland analogy) -- Dinner etiquette and chocolate lovers -- Desire swears by the first circle -- "Things are changing" -- What can possibly go wrong?
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #42: "Brief Lives:2"

quotation.p: "I mean, does this always happen when a girlfriend walks out on him?"
"Not at all. For example, after the Nada affair he razed the Dreaming. It was a bleak, lonely desert for centures. I remember the first flower that grew. The first time he smiled again...
quotation.source: Matthew and Lucien, in SANDMAN #42: "Brief Lives:2"

quotation.p: She was no longer Delight, and the blossoms had already begun to fall in her domain, becoming smudged and formless colours, and she had no one to talk to...
quotation.source: Delight becomes Delirium, in SANDMAN #42: "Brief Lives:2"

quotation.p: There are roughly seventy people walking the Earth, human to all appearances (and in a few cases, to all medical tests currently available), who were alive before the Earth had begun to congeal from gas and dust.
quotation.source: Some backstory, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: There are less than five hundred living humans who remember the human civilizations that predated the great lizards. (There were a few; fossil records are unreliable. Several of them lasted for millions of years.)
quotation.source: Some backstory, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "But I did okay, didn't I? I mean I got, what, fifteen thousand years. That's pretty good, isn't it? I lived a pretty long time."
"You lived what anybody gets, Bernie. You got a lifetime. No more. No less."
quotation.source: Bernie Capax and Death, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: The people who remember Atlantis -- Concerning mammoths, and falling walls -- Who controls transportation? -- Bored, she makes little frogs -- Truth Or Consequences, and other places -- Ancestral voices prophesying -- The dogs of art -- "When I dream, sometimes I remember how to fly."
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "What's the name of the word for the precise moment when you realize that you've actually forgotten how it felt to make love to somebody you really liked a long time ago."
"There isn't one."
"Oh. I thought maybe there was."
quotation.source: Delirium and Dream, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "Can I have a name?"
"Don't you have one? ... If you don't have a name, what do people call you? I mean, do they just wave and smile, or jingle little silver bells or what?"
quotation.source: The receptionist and Delirium, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: Well, there are these two people here, Sir. The man says he drank wine with you somewhere called Babylon, and the lady... she's making little frogs.
quotation.source: The receptionist, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "I'm not asking for art criticism, Barnabas. Merely for a few honest words of appreciation."
"Honestly? Well, the perspective's shot to hell, the colours could be better chosen, and the olive tree on the left looks like an overgrown stinging nettle."
quotation.source: Destruction and Barnabas, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "Hmph. What the hell would you know? You're a dog."
"Did I ever say I wasn't?"
quotation.source: Destruction and Barnabas, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "'The colours could be better chosen my foot.' Anyway -- I thought dogs were colour blind."
"Yeah? That's a coincidence. I mean, looking at that painting I thought you were colour blind."
quotation.source: Destruction and Barnabas, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "You know, Barnabas, there are those who claim that for unquestioning respect and eternal devotion, all one needs is a dog."
"Hey, schmuck, devotion you've got. Perjury isn't in the job description."
quotation.source: Destruction and Barnabas, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: When I dream, sometimes I remember how to fly. You just lift one leg, then you lift the other leg, and you're not standing on anything, and you can fly.
quotation.source: Chloe Russell, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: "So what I want to know is, when I'm asleep, do I really remember how to fly? And forget how when I wake up? Or am I just dreaming I can fly?"
"When you dream, sometimes you remember. When you wake, you always forget."
"But that's not fair..."
"No."
quotation.source: Chloe and Dream, in SANDMAN #43: "Brief Lives:3"

quotation.p: The other side of the sky -- A bear and his shadow -- Departed secrets -- "Twinkle's a nice word. So's viridian." -- Three keys -- A treatise on optics -- The perils of smoking in bed.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #44: "Brief Lives:4"

quotation.p: "Listen, I couldn't help overhearing you earlier. You said destiny was blind. Well, didn't you mean love? It's 'Love is blind'. That's the saying, isn't it?"
"The subject is one I find entirely lacking in interest."
quotation.source: Ruby and Dream, in SANDMAN #44: "Brief Lives:4"

quotation.p: Capax is dead. There is no doubt of that. There is nothing in his space but darkness and cold and silence.
quotation.source: Delirium checks on their quarry, in SANDMAN #44: "Brief Lives:4"

quotation.p: Etain of the Second Look: things moving fast. Strange impressions, difficult to locate. No longer where she was. Is she still even in this plane? Refuge. She's taken refuge somewhere. Delirium extends her flickering consciousness. An old power? Something obscuring her vision? Possibly.
quotation.source: Delirium checks on their quarry, in SANDMAN #44: "Brief Lives:4"

quotation.p: Do they think that they can impale the soul of it on their knives? That if they cut deep enough they can extract its dreams, naked and writhing and screaming, from its head? Reason is a flawed tool at best, my brother.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #44: "Brief Lives:4"

quotation.p: The things we do to be loved -- Her hands do not go to the moon -- The driving instructor -- Tiffany watches I -- White knights and/or pond scum -- Are dalmatians flowers? -- Nancy displays her erudition -- Wham bam thank you ma'am -- Tiffany watches II.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: "You. Out of the car, and keep your hands where I can see them."
"You mean not make my hands go to the moon or anywhere?"
quotation.source: A state trooper and Delirium, in SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: "Matthew. When you were a man, were you able to drive a motor vehicle?"
"Could I? Hey, I killed myself drunk driving, didn't I? I mean, the first time."
"I am not convinced that is any recommendation. However..."
quotation.source: Dream and Matthew, in SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: She finds herself thinking once more about the women in the temple courtyard. There is a magic generated by money given for lust. Once on a time, she could use that magic, draw it to her. Create an aspect, take the power to herself. Now, she uses a shadow of it to survive. Even a little worship is better than nothing.
quotation.source: Ishtar, in SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: I know how gods begin, Roger. We start as dreams. Then we walk out of dreams into the land. We are worshipped and loved, and take power to ourselves. And then one day there's no one left to worship us. And in the end, each little god and goddess takes its last journey back into dreams... and what comes after, not even we know.
quotation.source: Ishtar, in SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: I'm going to dance now, I'm afraid.
quotation.source: Ishtar ends it all, in SANDMAN #45: "Brief Lives:5"

quotation.p: Life isn't pleasant, petrified -- The parting of the ways -- The trouble with mortals -- Dreamings of meeting or meetings of dreaming? -- The trouble with gods -- Mervyn sets him straight -- "Have you got anything with a happy ending?" -- Tempus frangit.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #46: "Brief Lives:6"

quotation.p: "Ruby's dead?"
"Yes."
"Ah me. That's the trouble with mortals. They do that. Not to worry, eh?"
quotation.source: Dream and Pharamond, in SANDMAN #46: "Brief Lives:6"

quotation.p: At the edge of the desert is the City of Bubastis. The City is Bubastis as she never was, save in the dreams of a long-dead builder; and in the dreams of a blind child dead four thousand years, who had never seen the city she lived in all her short life; and in the dreams of the goddess of that place. The dreams of Bast.
quotation.source: Dream builds a dream city, in SANDMAN #46: "Brief Lives:6"

quotation.p: These are the ghosts of those of my folk who were embalmed, that they would live forever in the world beyond. But their physical forms were exhumed, over a hundred years ago, ground up and used to fertilize the land. Now they are only memories, slowly fading from the land and the world. Dreams of ghost cats, and cats of ghost dreams... sss. I know how they feel.
quotation.source: Bast, in SANDMAN #46: "Brief Lives:6"

quotation.p: Cooking considered as one of the fine arts -- "My envelope isn't any good anymore" -- Where all mazes meet -- The other side of the coin -- Life as a glass of bitter wine -- Cherries are counted, and a bargain is made -- An unlikely growth.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #47: "Brief Lives:7"

quotation.p: Dream respects his brother, but the garden of Destiny disturbs him. It is usual, however, for the Endless to feel uncomfortable in each other's realms; only Death travels wheresoever she must, without misgiving.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #47: "Brief Lives:7"

quotation.p: The garden of Destiny. Look behind you: shadow-plays of memory are forever being enacted, on paths you walked too long ago.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #47: "Brief Lives:7"

quotation.p: Do you know why I stopped being Delight, my brother? I do. There are things not in your book. There are paths outside this garden. You would do well to remember that.
quotation.source: Delirium berates Destiny, in SANDMAN #47: "Brief Lives:7"

quotation.p: Journey's end -- Brains, a heart, a ride in a balloon -- Dinner -- Something new -- The illusion of permanence -- A wreath of bright stars -- Echoes of darkness -- Up. Out.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: Ah, yes. You must have grown on a particularly penetrating and incisive branch of the family tree.
quotation.source: Barnabas to Delirium, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: I suppose I had vaguely hoped that you had changed, my brother. That you'd noticed that there were other people in the world. That you had begun to see people as other than things that dream, as creatures of stories.
quotation.source: Destruction to Dream, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: Destruction did not cease with my abandonment of my realm, no more than people would cease to dream should you abandon yours. Perhaps it's more uncontrolled, wilder. Perhaps not. But it's no longer anyone's responsibility.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: I like the stars. It's the illusion of permanence, I think. I mean, they're always flaring up and caving in and going out. But from here, I can pretend... I can pretend that things last. I can pretend that lives last longer than moments. Gods come, and gods go. Mortals flicker and flash and fade. Worlds don't last; and stars and galaxies are transient, fleeting things that twinkle like fireflies and vanish into cold and dust. But I can pretend.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #48: "Journey's End"

quotation.p: The Endless? The Endless are merely patterns. The Endless are ideas. The Endless are wave functions. The Endless are repeating motifs. The Endless are echoes of darkness, and nothing more. We have no right to play with their lives, to order their dreams and their desires.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: "And even our existences are brief and bounded. None of us will last longer than this version of the universe."
"Except our sister."
"So we suppose."
quotation.source: Destruction, Delirium, and Dream in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: Desire was right. Also untrustworthy, acerbic, dangerous, and cruel. But right. You would have been better off leaving well enough alone.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: Still, what's done can't be undone. Or very rarely. And definitely not this time.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #48: "Brief Lives:8"

quotation.p: Farewells -- Answered prayers -- The flowers of romance -- Journey's end -- The gates of horn -- Things unlooked for -- Brief lives.
quotation.source: Title of SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: I am so scared. It's strange. For many thousand years I have prayed for death. I have prayed to all the gods for peace and relief and... I have prayed for an ending.
quotation.source: Orpheus, in SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: "You cannot seek Destruction and return unscathed."
"Delirium has."
"Delirium has been scathed enough in her time."
quotation.source: Despair and Desire, in SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: And from the horns of the youngest, he carved a gate that he reserved for true dreams. This because he had some little regard for her, and had, perhaps, in some small measure, regretted the course of action he had found necessary. But all this was long ago; and the truth of it all has not ever been told on this world.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: At rest in the temple of its body, Desire, who would be darkly amused to hear itself described as an angel, floats in an eyeball larger than a cathedral, and remembers its lost brother in its own way. Desire's thoughts are private. It holds a small red flower, very tightly.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: Andros takes the linen-wrapped bundle from his son. We will put him to rest, thinks Andros Rhodocanakis, beneath the cherry tree, and perhaps his spirit is in Elysium, with his beloved Eurydice. And perhaps his spirit has returned to darkness, or to nothing... And perhaps he is at rest.
quotation.source: Orpheus's burial, in SANDMAN #49: "Brief Lives:9"

quotation.p: I don't really like driving in snow. There's something about the motion of the falling snowflakes that hurts my eyes, throwing my sense of balance all to hell. It's like tumbling into a field of stars.
quotation.source: Brant's thoughts on driving, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: Matey, if you asks my opinion, a-sitting there in the snow is not eggzackerly the smartest thingie as you could be a-doing of, all things considerable.
quotation.source: A passing hedgehog offers some advice, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: You need help, matey. You and that there young lady. That red stuff, that's blood that is. Meant to be on the inside, it is. Bad sign if it's not on the inside, that's what I says.
quotation.source: Medical advice from a hedgehog, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: Up the lane aways is the Inn. You just have to be sure it's there, though. If you aren't sure, then fizzlywinks, it's only goin' to be fireflies and treeses.
quotation.source: Giving directions, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: "What's going on?"
"We're telling stories. You just missed a really good one about a man who won November 1937 in a poker game."
quotation.source: Brant and Charlene, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: In the subway train, in the morning, he would read a newspaper, and wonder what would happen were the subway carriage to be transported to a distant planet: how long would it take before the passengers began to speak, one to another; who would make love to whom; who would be eaten should they run out of food. He felt vaguely ashamed of these daydreams.
quotation.source: Robert's daily life, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: A carving on a wall above a door on a condemned house; a bright flash of sunlight reflecting off the railings of a park, making them serried spears to guard the green grass and running children; a gravestone in a churchyard, eroded by wind and rain and time until the words on the stone had been lost but the mosses and lichens still spelled out letters from forgotten alphabets... all these sights, and many others, he treasured and collected.
quotation.source: Robert's lunchtime walks, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: The roads mixed him up, turned him around. Here, he would pass a cathedral or museum, there, a skyscraper or a fountain -- always hauntingly familiar. But he never passed the same landmark twice, could never find the road to return him to the landmark again.
quotation.source: Wandering a city of dreams, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: So, if a city has a personality, maybe it also has a soul. Maybe it dreams. That is where I believe we have come. We are in the dreams of the city. That's why certain places hover on the brink of recognition; why we almost know where we are.
quotation.source: The old man's theory, in SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: "If the city was dreaming," he told me, "then the city is asleep. And I do not fear cities sleeping, stretched out unconscious around their rivers and estuaries, like cats in the moonlight. Sleeping cities are tame and harmless things. What I fear," he said, "is that one day he cities will waken. That one day the cities will rise."
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: I like to believe it was only the cold that made me shiver, only a strand of fog in my throat that caused me to catch my breath.
Robert walked away across the moor and I never saw him again. Since that time I have walked with less comfort in cities.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #51: "A Tale of Two Cities"

quotation.p: "So... where are you from?"
"Seattle. You?"
"The Necropolis Litharge."
quotation.source: Bathroom conversation, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: I lack the ability to embellish. Thus you would perforce needs content all yourselves, one and all, with a rather sparse and uninteresting narrative.
quotation.source: Cluracan warms up, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: "Sometimes I wish that my ambassador was not quite so... let me see. Feckless?"
"You reign over a feckless dominion, My Lady."
quotation.source: Queen Titania and Cluracan, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: Well, you are the best I have, Cluracan, and to say that is to say little indeed.
quotation.source: Queen Titania, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: We of Faerie are of the wild magic. We are not creatures of spells and grimoires. We are spells, and we are written of in grimoires.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: Cluracan, it is one to me whether you live or die. It is not one to your sister, and she serves me well and faithfully. I would not see her needlessly distressed.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: "Was that the truth, Cluracan?"
"All of it except the sword-fight with the palace guard, which I threw in to add verisimilitude, excitement, and local color to an otherwise bald and insipid narrative."
quotation.source: The innkeeper and Cluracan, in SANDMAN #52: "Cluracan's Tale"

quotation.p: I stood there sweating with the line in my hands, and the sun broke above the horizon, and the gulls mewed and the grey sea turned to sapphire: and I knew this would be a good voyage.
quotation.source: The Sea Witch sets sail, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: "You're a romantic."
"Why be a sailor if you're not?"
quotation.source: First mate Canby and Jim, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: "Why does the water glow like that?"
"The dream magic of the sea."
"Phosphorescent algae."
quotation.source: One question, two answers, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: Some of it's the voice, and some of it's the hands, and a lot of it's learning to see what you see and not what you think you see, if that makes any sense.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: "How old are you, sir?"
"Old enough to have learned to keep my mouth shut about seeing a bloody great snake in the middle of the ocean."
quotation.source: Jim and Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: Given time, you'll spin a yarn of what we saw in the ocean. Given time I'll tell the tale of the handsome cabin boy. But given enough time and the right audience, the darkest of secrets scum over into mere curiosities.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: But I'm getting too old for the trick, which troubles me, for the sea is in my blood like a fever and I don't know how I can leave.
quotation.source: Jim's envoi, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: And when, some day soon, I forsake the sea -- like a sailor leaving his lady-love on the shore -- I shall take another name to me and build another life.
But -- for now -- you can call me Jim.
quotation.source: Jim's envoi, in SANDMAN #53: "Hob's Leviathan"

quotation.p: My people have, of old, divided the world into two kinds of people: hedgehogs and foxes. Hedgehogs know one big thing. Foxes know lots of little things.
quotation.source: The storyteller paraphrases Isaiah Berlin, in SANDMAN #54: "The Golden Boy"

quotation.p: In the White House is a tiger skin rug, shot and killed many years ago by Teddy Roosevelt. The feet of the great walk over that tiger skin each day. It listens to policy being formed and secrets being spoken. Now do you think that tiger would rather be dead and in the seat of power, or alive, and walking the jungle of India, sniffing the wind for the scent of game?
quotation.source: Prez Rickard, in SANDMAN #54: "The Golden Boy"

quotation.p: Some people said the woman who killed his Kathy returned to finish off the task she had begun years before. And these people knew that the killer had in her turn been executed. But still, they said, it was her.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN #54: "The Golden Boy"

quotation.p: "So what are you? God? Or the Devil?"
"I'm just Boss Smiley. I run your world."
"So that girl was right. You're not the watchmaker."
"If only."
quotation.source: Prez Rickard and Boss Smiley, in SANDMAN #54: "The Golden Boy"

quotation.p: Firstly, earth burial or interment. Variants are boxed, wrapped or naked, embalmed or otherwise; lying, seated or standing; grave, sepulchre, vault or cairn.
quotation.source: Part one of Petrefax's answer, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: Secondly, disposal through fire. Variants: clothed, boxed, pyre, vessel, or ship. Also there are different procedures that can be adopted to dispose of the ashes.
quotation.source: Part two of Petrefax's answer, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: Thirdly: mummification. Variants: salting, mineral baths, dehydration. There's the thing with pitch and bitumen and...
quotation.source: Part three of Petrefax's answer, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: Fourthly, disposal through water. Variants include feeding to water animals or fish; disposal in sacred river or sea, boxing, bagging with rocks, dismemberment...
quotation.source: Part four of Petrefax's answer, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: Fifth... Air burial, sir. Variants include dismemberment and otherwise; ingestion by raptors or scavengers; complete or partial disposal.
quotation.source: Part five of Petrefax's answer, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: It is a fearful thing to be haunted by those who loved us once. It is a fearful thing to haunt those one loves.
quotation.source: Destruction orates about death (small 'd'), in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: We were here before any other city that now stands. And we will sing the funeral songs that are sung for cities for them when they die.
quotation.source: The role of the Necropolis Litharge, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: And then she found herself in a huge room, somewhere beneath the city. There were six silver cerements hanging in that room, shining in the darkness; and a huge book, locked closed, on a lectern. And a voice said to her: "WHICH OF THEM IS DEAD?"
quotation.source: Young Mistress Veltis makes a discovery, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: "We're all dead. That's why we're here."
"Young man. If you were dead, I think I would know it. I have some experience in these matters."
quotation.source: Brant Tucker and Master Klaproth, in SANDMAN #55: "Cerements"

quotation.p: I think that the Cluracan has had enough. I know he prides himself on his capacity for alcohol, but there's a thin line between intoxication and unconsciousness, and he's just about to cross it.
quotation.source: The innkeeper, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: When a world ends, there's always something left over. A story, perhaps, or a vision, or a hope. This inn is a refuge, after the lights go out. For a while.
quotation.source: The innkeeper, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: It is, however, a difficult hypothesis to test empirically. This is only the second of these storms in my lifetime, and we centaurs consider ourselves a long-lived folk indeed.
quotation.source: Chiron, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: So, like everyone else, I was staring out of one of the windows of the inn at the end of the words.
Worlds. I meant worlds.
quotation.source: Brant Tucker, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: The words said over my father's body were hollow and dumb, and I couldn't find it in me to cry, not then. I knew I was watching the real thing here. There was true grief in each step they took across the sky, and they shouldered the casket as if they were shouldering the weight of the world.
quotation.source: Brant Tucker, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: She looked at me. Maybe she was trying to tell me something; I don't know. She probably didn't even know I was there. But I'll always love her. All my life.
quotation.source: Brant Tucker sees Death, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: But it was like I knew her. Like she was my oldest, dearest friend. The kind of person you can tell anything to, no matter how bad, and they'll still love you, because they know you.
quotation.source: Brant Tucker sees Death, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: "Hey. Thanks for listening. I suppose you must think I'm crazy."
"No. I don't. Maybe I ought to. But I don't. You hear a lot of weird stories behind a bar."
quotation.source: Brant Tucker and the bartender, in SANDMAN #56: "World's End"

quotation.p: There's a moment of fear in the returning to sleep. A hesitation: there are darknesses beyond the curtain of waking, and the shadow-plays clutch at my heart... Too late. I'm gone.
quotation.source: The unnamed dreamer, in SANDMAN: "The Castle"

quotation.p: Get your head outta the clouds! Not you, kiddo. I was talking to Tiny. He gets his head in the clouds, he'll be sneezing for days.
quotation.source: Mervyn Pumpkinhead, in SANDMAN: "The Castle"

quotation.p: I'm Matthew. I'm the raven. Not a raven -- the raven. That's one of the weird things about the Dreaming -- it's a kind of one-raven-at-a-time sort of place.
quotation.source: Matthew introduces himself, in SANDMAN: "The Castle"

quotation.p: Can't say I've ever been too fond of beginnings, myself. Messy little things. Give me a good ending any time. You know where you are with an ending.
quotation.source: The eldest of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: Why, that's what I like about making things for people. You can start off in Birmingham and finish in, well, Tanganyika or somewhere.
quotation.source: The middle of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: It's never what they want, and if we give them what they think they want, they like it less than ever. "I never thought it would be like this." "Why can't it be like the one I had before?" I don't know why we bother.
quotation.source: The eldest of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: We bother because we have no choice. Because that is what we are, in this aspect.
quotation.source: The youngest of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: There are no gryphons, no wyverns, no winged horses in the waking world, raven. Not anymore. But we are here...
quotation.source: The gryphon at the door, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: "Mervyn, build an ocean over here, knock down that city under the willow tree over there, and incidentally, Mervyn, this time remember that ice is customarily cold." Like I don't have enough to do.
quotation.source: Mervyn complains about his boss Dream, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: "Whatcha reading?"
"An unwritten play by John Webster. A Banquet for the Wormes."
"Any good?"
"Yes. Very good. 'Webster was much possessed by death and saw the skull beneath the skin.' He did, you know, he really did."
"Yeah? You mean like he had some sort of X-ray vision?"
"No, nothing like that."
quotation.source: Matthew and Lucien, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: "Lucien? Were you ever alive?"
"I don't think so, no."
"You don't think so?"

"I can remember the title, author, and location of every book in this library, Matthew. Every book that's ever been dreamed. Every book that's ever been imagined. Every book that's ever been lost. Millions upon millions of them. That's what I remember. It's my job. Other things... I forget sometimes."
quotation.source: Matthew and Lucien, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"
