quotation.p: Imagine that you woke in the night and rose, and seemed to see before you another person, whom slowly you perceived to be yourself. Someone had entered in the night and placed a mirror in your sleeping place, made from a black metal. You had been frightened only of your reflection. But then the reflection slowly raised one hand, while your own hand stayed still...
A dark mirror... That was always the intention...
quotation.source: Dream explains the Corinthian, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: No, I'm afraid not. It is a song I find entirely devoid of interest. The melody is trite, while the awkward paraphrases of lesser Eliot poems in the lyrics are grating in the extreme.
quotation.source: Lucifer gives his opinion of Andrew Lloyd Webber, in SANDMAN #57: "The Kindly Ones:1"

quotation.p: "Are you sure it's a finger? It's very small."
"It was a very small baby."
"Ditch-delivered?"
"And birth-strangled. Just like it says in the recipe."
quotation.source: From Lyta's dream of the three Ladies, in SANDMAN #58: "The Kindly Ones:2"

quotation.p: "I didn't know that there was a downstairs, here."
"There's a downstairs in everybody. That's where we live."
quotation.source: Lyta and the youngest of the Three, in SANDMAN #58: "The Kindly Ones:2"

quotation.p: "Here -- have a porkie pie instead."
"It -- it's covered in mud."
"Everyone's got to eat a peck of dirt before they die."
quotation.source: One of the Three and Lyta, in SANDMAN #58: "The Kindly Ones:2"

quotation.p: "Fairy gifts traditionally are double-edged knives."
"And are your own gifts always without consequence, Sire?"
quotation.source: Dream and Cluracan, in SANDMAN #58: "The Kindly Ones:2"

quotation.p: "Many years ago I convinced Thor of the Aesir that the reason for his impotence was that he was pregnant."
"Pregnant?"
"Mm. He's not very bright."
quotation.source: Loki and Puck, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: Somebody once told me you don't really die until everyone that you knew is dead, too. Think of all the people I'm keeping alive, eh?
quotation.source: Hob Gadling at a graveside, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: I wish I could have told you about Peg. You'd've liked her. She died in the Blitz. We were trapped in a cellar. I held her hand, as she stopped breathing... Ah, but that's the past, and done with.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: It was then that Delirium noticed that she had absent-mindedly transformed into a hundred and eleven perfect, tiny multicoloured fish. Each fish sang a different song.
quotation.source: In SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: Dreams are tricky buggers. You can't trust them.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: Watch me. This is me going to the door, just like I've done thousands and thousands of times in the past and none of those times was important, I can't even remember them as individual times, who remembers walking to the door...? And then I open the door.
quotation.source: Lyta Hall, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: This is me walking into the family room. This is me just standing here listening to the voices in my head. One of them's saying "this is me just standing here..." And the other one's going "Eeeeeee..." in one long ceaseless scream. And the last one doesn't say anything at all.
quotation.source: Lyta is told her son is dead, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: I must be strong. And in my head a voice says, Yes, Dear, you must. And in my head another voice is muttering Oh that I were a man, or that I had power to execute my apprehended wishes: I would whip some with scorpions... And a voice says, You know what you must do.
quotation.source: Lyta is told her son is dead, in SANDMAN #59: "The Kindly Ones:3"

quotation.p: "The early bird catches the worm, Star of Morning. The, um, worm that dieth not, in this case. Eh? Haha..."
"How remarkably funny, Remiel. Not actually original though, of course."
quotation.source: Remiel and Lucifer, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: Been there, Remiel. Done that, wore the tee-shirt, ate the burger, bought the original cast album, choreographed the legions of the damned and orchestrated the screaming...
quotation.source: Lucifer, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: You didn't join the rebellion, not because you felt I was wrong, but because you were too damned scared. What would you have done, had I won? Told me that you'd always supported me ideologically? That you were secretly cheering me on the whole time?
quotation.source: Lucifer berates Remiel, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: "Do you want to come with me, kitty-cat?"

"I can't. I'm on my way to that castle. It's owned by a shape-changing ogre. I intend to wager the silver collar around my neck that the ogre cannot change itself into three things that I shall name for it."
"Will the third shape be a mouse?"
"Of course."
"But... don't they ever learn?"
"They can't. They're part of the story, just as I am."
quotation.source: Lyta and a passing cat, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: I didn't say it was my fault. I said it was my responsibility. I know the difference.
quotation.source: Rose Walker, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: "Y'see, my grandmother was Carmilla Bristol."
"Who?"

"Carmilla Bristol. She played, like, every black ladies' maid in every crappy Hollywood film made between 1925 and 1950. "Now dere, Missy, you hush up wid' yo' cryin'." She didn't get to demonstrate much dramatic range, but she had a great eye for a land deal."
quotation.source: Carla and Rose, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: Our sister died. But we never took revenge. We knew there'd be trouble one day, her being mortal. It's not as if we never said anything. We still miss her. We still mourn.
quotation.source: Stheno, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: Take apples, by all means -- I'm guardian -- to be honest, don't give a toss who has them -- no one ever comes here. Just rot on the ground -- worms get them -- pity.
quotation.source: Geryon, guardian of the Tree of Life, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: "A complete what, Mervyn?"
"A, uh, just a... complete, Boss."
"Completeness is a virtue, is it not?"
quotation.source: Dream and Mervyn, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: It has always been the prerogative of children and half-wits to point out that the emperor has no clothes. But the half-wit remains a half-wit, and the emperor remains an emperor.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #60: "The Kindly Ones:4"

quotation.p: The gods we prayed to when we were young used up their time so long ago. They cannot answer anymore.
quotation.source: Euryale, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: "They never liked us, did they?"
"Gods don't 'like'. They love and they hate and they ignore."
quotation.source: Stheno and Euryale, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: "It was good to be three. I haven't forgotten... Twos don't work. Twos hurt and crumble. Twos fall into ones, and then into dust and nothings."
"We're still here."
"That's because we haven't given up hope of being a three again."
quotation.source: Euryale and Stheno, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: If you go looking for the Ladies... well, I don't know that that's such a good idea. You might find them.
quotation.source: Euryale, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: Can I have more water, please? My hair drank most of it.
quotation.source: Lyta Hall, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: "You know, there's a three-headed snake out in the garden. I don't think it trusts you two. It was rude about you."
"Well, then the next time we see it, we'll glare at it."
quotation.source: Lyta Hall and Euryale, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: "If you had stayed with us, we could have given you life until death."
"Don't I get that anyway?"
quotation.source: Stheno and Lyta Hall, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: There's a theory that for a human to be killed by a god is the best thing that could possibly happen to the human under discussion. It eliminates all questions of belief, while manifestly placing a human life at the service of a higher power.
quotation.source: Loki, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: You don't have to believe in God. But what about gods? Eh? The plurality of powers and dominions. The lords and ladies of field and thorn, of asphalt and sewer, gods of telephone and whore, gods of hospital and car-crash?
quotation.source: Loki, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: And do you know your tragedy, Carla? ... It's that, for all your goodwill, for all your willingness to help, you never knew what any of this was all about. What was going on. You don't know how it ends. And you'll never get to find out.
quotation.source: Loki, in SANDMAN #61: "The Kindly Ones:5"

quotation.p: I stay awake the whole way, this time, while Jack does the conversation thing that the English do so well, where they can talk forever and never tell you a thing.
quotation.source: Rose Walker, in SANDMAN #62: "The Kindly Ones:6"

quotation.p: And as soon as he was sure that he was dead, he got up and shook himself, and looked around, and there waiting for him on the bed was his wife, with long claws out, and her eyes blazing like a green cat ready to spring.
quotation.source: Magda's story, in SANDMAN #62: "The Kindly Ones:6"

quotation.p: And he screams, "Kill me, for god's sake, just get it over with." But she licks her lips with a long worm tongue, and she shakes her head. "A meal this good must never be hurried," she says. "Just hold still, boy, and let me enjoy myself." And she takes her first, gentle bite from his cheek with her sharp sharp teeth...
And that's the story, as my mother used to tell it.
quotation.source: Magda's story, in SANDMAN #62: "The Kindly Ones:6"

quotation.p: Well, there was this doggy. He was a very clever doggy. He said things like... like... "I would feel infinitely more comfortable in your presence if you would agree to treat gravity as a law, rather than one of a number of suggested options."
quotation.source: Delirium describes her dog Barnabas, in SANDMAN #63: "The Kindly Ones:7"

quotation.p: A raven walks slowly about her house, its frock-coated gait that of an elderly gentleman, leaning forward as it struts. A black hound waits by the door. In the garden by the stream a little girl plays with something yellowed and round that might conceivably be a ball.
quotation.source: The house of the Morrigan, in SANDMAN #63: "The Kindly Ones:7"

quotation.p: And then, to conclude the day's work, he gave an elderly tortoise, alone on her island these past two centuries, a dream of her love, roasted by passing sailors long since for his rich green flesh.
quotation.source: From a week in Dream's life, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: Dancing salamanders brought the children silver plates filled with exotic ice-creams of various flavors, and with fruits they had never seen before and would never see again... although they would dream of them, on rare occasions, until they died.
quotation.source: From a week in Dream's life, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: He spoke to the embryonic silicon dreams who clustered in a far ballroom, and whispered to them, briefly, about the other machines that had dreamed in the distant past.
quotation.source: From a week in Dream's life, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: He spoke to the scar-dancers, to the straw-dust-women, to the old man with a swan's arm who tends the back stairs, to the three children of the autopsy, to the painters and the scriveners and the walls.
quotation.source: From a week in Dream's life, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: I know lots of things. People think I don't but I really do. I know more about us than any of us. That's just one of the things I know.
quotation.source: Delirium, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: Sometimes old memories surface, like flotsam on the churning surface of the sea. And then they are gone.
quotation.source: The Corinthian, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: Some were larger than eagles. Some were older than gods. They stayed in the shadows, kawwing and tokking. Waiting.
quotation.source: The ravens arrive in the Dreaming, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: Gryphon, you are old. Your flesh is meat, and the meat is decaying. Your bones are dry and brittle. Within you now, lion and eagle abandon their battle for dominance, and surrender to time and to the grave.
quotation.source: The Furies kill the gryphon, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: "I am honor-bound to warn you to stay on the path through the castle. Straying from the path could mean your destruction. ... You killed my friend, woman. Stray from your path."
quotation.source: The guardian dragon warns the Furies, in SANDMAN #64: "The Kindly Ones:8"

quotation.p: Love takes hostages. It gets inside you. It eats you out and leaves you crying in the darkness, so a simple phrase like "maybe we should just be friends" or "how very perceptive" turns into a glass splinter working its way into your heart.
quotation.source: Rose Walker's soliloquy, in SANDMAN #65: "The Kindly Ones:9"

quotation.p: "I... I did not intend to hurt you."
"And what if you did not? Intent and outcome are so rarely coincident."
quotation.source: Dream and Larissa, in SANDMAN #65: "The Kindly Ones:9"

quotation.p: The thing you ought to remember about ravens, is that we belong equally to both genders. You don't see that every day. But we're as likely to be the Morrigan's as Odin's, as likely to be Eve's as Dream's.
quotation.source: Noah's raven, in SANDMAN #65: "The Kindly Ones:9"

quotation.p: "So, young Matthew. You want to go first?"
"I can't. He was my friend. I just came down to say goodbye."
"So? Listen, an eye's just an eye. A few more days, and he'll be something not even a raven would eat. Over to the ants..."
quotation.source: Noah's raven and Matthew, in SANDMAN #65: "The Kindly Ones:9"

quotation.p: It was like a bad TV show. "He's a reincarnated serial killer -- his partner's a bird. They're cops."
quotation.source: Matthew the raven, in SANDMAN #65: "The Kindly Ones:9"

quotation.p: A Puck is harder by far to hurt than some little lord of malice from the lands of ice and snow. We Pucks are old and hard and wild...
quotation.source: Robin Goodfellow, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: I am the Puck, called Robin Goodfellow. I am a trickster, an antic prankster, a will o' the wisp. "Things fall apart, the centre cannot hold, mere anarchy is loose upon the world." That's me.
quotation.source: Robin Goodfellow, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: "You can't kill me."
"We can. If we want to. You scarcely exist. You're a dream of a ghost of a memory of someone who, one suspects, never existed in the first place."
quotation.source: Abel and the Furies, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: You mustn't kill me. You don't love me. You d-don't even know me.
quotation.source: The Furies kill Abel, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: I swear on my name, soon he will be remembered only by antiquaries. But then, we are all improved by the glow of memory.
quotation.source: Robin Goodfellow predicts Dream's demise, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: "You? What are you?"
"Me? Lady, I'm your worst nightmare -- a pumpkin with a gun."
quotation.source: The Furies and Mervyn, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: They say I'm a bastard, and I'll tell you what. I am a bastard. A hard, tough bastard. A tough, hard bastard with a pumpkin for a head.
quotation.source: Mervyn rallies his troops, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: "Gods fear us. Demons fear us. We have hounded kings and angels. We have taken vengeance on worlds and universes. We are the Kindly Ones. We are the Eumenides."
"Yeah? Well, Eumenides this!"
quotation.source: The Furies and Mervyn, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: "How... how dare you let that happen, Lord? How dare you?"
"You will not speak to me like that, Lucien."
"I doubt I'll be alive tomorrow, Lord. On that basis I find it particularly easy to say exactly what I think."
quotation.source: Lucien and Dream, in SANDMAN #66: "The Kindly Ones:10"

quotation.p: Things have been a little turbulent of late. Late being the operative word.
quotation.source: Cain watches the Dreaming crumble, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: "On reflection, while I cannot give you the thing itself, I could give you a dream of my love."
"I already have that, my Lord."
quotation.source: Dream and Nuala, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: I remember waiting for his return. I remember the strange strained grey days that stretched into years and into decades. The slow crumbling of walls... the rooms that were no longer there...
quotation.source: The Corinthian remembers Dream's absence, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"
Destiny, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: All around me darkness gathers, fading is the sun that shone, we must speak of other matters, you can be me when I'm gone...
quotation.source: The train's clattering, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: Such a train it becomes, oh! a gleaming black and silver Deco dream of a train that clacks along the silver tracks with the unchanging rhythm of a nursery rhyme, and perhaps, if you listened hard enough, you could imagine that you could tease words from the pulsing clatter...
quotation.source: Dream's conveyance, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: Above the entrance is a frieze: a wyvern and a winged horse are frozen in bas-relief, and there is an empty space, where a third carving might once have been.
quotation.source: The train terminus, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: And this occurs at the same moment that a customer at Lux's, drunk and flirtatious, peeks beneath Mazikeen's half-mask. He satisfies his curiosity, as he loses, one after the other, his drink, his lunch, and his sanity. Mazikeen has no patience with men.
quotation.source: A brief aside, in SANDMAN #67: "The Kindly Ones:11"

quotation.p: Hmph. If you don't let me in, I will turn you into a demon half-face waitress night-club lady with a crush on her boss, and I'll make it so you've been that from the beginning of time to now and you'll never ever know if you were anything else and it will itch inside your head worse than little bugses.
quotation.source: Delirium threatens Mazikeen, in SANDMAN #68: "The Kindly Ones:12"

quotation.p: So: exeunt the spider women, stage left. Look on their works, ye mighty, and clean yours with bleach.
quotation.source: Hal's reaction to Zelda's death, in SANDMAN #68: "The Kindly Ones:12"

quotation.p: "You're crying."
"Lord Shaper is in dire need, and he doesn't love me."
"Would it be better if he was in dire need, and did love you?"
quotation.source: Cluracan and Nuala, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: Since I killed my son... the Dreaming has not been the same ... or perhaps I was no longer the same. I still had my obligations... But even the freedom of the Dreaming can be a cage, of a kind, my sister.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: And the poison spills into Loki's mouth and eyes; he writhes, and a city falls: and in the moment of pain he gains a certain clarity. The master manipulator realizes how, ultimately-- how strangely, how elegantly-- he too had been manipulated. Perhaps the sound he makes is laughter.
quotation.source: Another aside, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: Dream? Give me your hand.
quotation.source: Death, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: "But I did look for you. All over."
"Hmph. Where were you looking? Patagonia? Mars? The Emerald City?"
"Um. Places like that."
quotation.source: Delirium and Barnabas, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: I had the hubris originally to regard myself as a collaborator, as a co-author. Very rapidly I found myself reduced to the status of character, following something of a disagreement in the fundamental direction of the Creation.
quotation.source: Lucifer, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: "So you see, it was innocent. It really was. Just bad luck."
"Rosalita... there isn't any innocent. There isn't any guilty. There's just dead."
quotation.source: Rose and Hal, at Zelda's funeral in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: "What did we make? What was it, in the end?"
"What it always is. A handful of yarn; a little weaving and stitching; some embroidering perhaps. A few loose ends, but that's only to be expected."
quotation.source: The Fates, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: It's the same old story... Whatever it turns into on the way, whatever it is you originally undertake to spin or knit or weave, keep it going long enough and, in the end, my lilies, it's always a winding sheet.
quotation.source: One of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: <snf> At least it's not a moral. Worse than beginnings, morals. I've got no time for them. No time at all.
quotation.source: One of the three Fates, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: Never mind. There. For good or bad. It's done.
quotation.source: It all comes down to this, in SANDMAN #69: "The Kindly Ones:13"

quotation.p: The family did not send to ask from whom the messenger had come; it was not the first time that messengers had visited them, after all. And there are some powers that no one, not even the Endless, seeks to inquire into too deeply.
quotation.source: Invitations are delivered in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"
Delirium, in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"

quotation.p: Our brother is dead. We have come for the cerements and for the books of ritual, which are in your keeping.
quotation.source: Desire, in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"

quotation.p: And the state of his bathroom -- I'm not one to gossip, but there are things crusted on his sink that have not simply developed intelligent life but have in all probability by now evolved their own political systems.
quotation.source: Cain describes Abel in in SANDMAN #70, "The Wake" part one

quotation.p: Eblis O'Shaughnessy: you were created and gifted by five of the Endless, but you can neither dream nor, ultimately, destroy, and that shall be your triumph and that shall be your tragedy.
quotation.source: Destiny, in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"

quotation.p: If you bring me back to life, my death will have no meaning. I had a fine existence. I was a good place. I spent a little time in the waking world. I even fell in love, once, a little. I lived a good life and it ended. Would you take that away from me?
quotation.source: Fiddler's Green, in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"

quotation.p: And the Lady Bast, her fur thinning and her eyes milky and dim, summons all the power at her disposal, pulls together tiny strands of belief, a handful of instants of half-hearted worship. At a cat show in Glasgow, a teenage boy stares at a one-year-old Abyssinian and, for a moment, he sees a goddess. Head held high, eyes clear, fur sleek, she walks to the Dreaming.
quotation.source: Bast prepares for the wake, in SANDMAN #70, part one of "The Wake"

quotation.p: Somewhere in the night, entities bigger than storm-clouds are building a house of remembrance. The people on the ground are waiting for the building to be finished before they go inside. They wait awkwardly, shuffling and making small-talk, in the wasteland that was once the heart of the Dreaming. Everybody's here. You're here.
quotation.source: Preparations, in SANDMAN #71, part two of "The Wake"

quotation.p: I am not here to mourn him. I mourned the loss of my love a long time ago. I am here to say goodbye to a stranger who once did me a good turn. And to the man who gave my son the death he craved.
quotation.source: Calliope, in SANDMAN #71, part two of "The Wake"

quotation.p: "Your predecessor, he told me there weren't any gryphons left in the waking world."
"Arimaspia is as far from the waking world as it is from the Dreaming, great lord."
quotation.source: Matthew and the new gryphon, in SANDMAN #71, part two of "The Wake"

quotation.p: "The one I hate is where I'm just an actor on a strange television version of my life. Have you ever had that dream?"
"Doesn't everyone?"
"I don't."
quotation.source: Superman, Batman, and Martian Manhunter, in SANDMAN #71, part two of "The Wake"

quotation.p: We were never loves, and we never will be, now. I do not regret that, however. I regret the conversations we never had, the time we did not spend together. I regret that I never told him that he made me happy, when I was in his company. The world was the better for his being in it. These things alone do I now regret: things left unsaid. And he is gone, and I am old.
quotation.source: Lady Bast, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: The bonds of family bind both ways. They bind us up, support us, help us, and they are also a bond from which it is difficult, perhaps impossible to extricate oneself.
quotation.source: Desire, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: I cared for him, very much. He was so wise; he seemed so certain of the rightness of his actions. And I, who do nothing but doubt, admired that in him. He was a creature of hope, for dreams are hopes, and echoes of hopes, and I am a creature of despair.
quotation.source: Despair, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: I think of the first Despair sometimes, said Despair. It must be over a hundred thousand years since anyone thought of her but me. An eyeblink, and she is forgotten. And you will forget: death or life will take him from your minds. I know, whispered Despair, in her distant, empty voice. But I shall remember him.
quotation.source: Despair, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: Something Dian used to say to me. She'd say, "Wes, don't say anything unless you've got something to say." Advice I took to heart. She would also say, "It's a long, long trail that has no turning." And how right she was.
quotation.source: Wesley Dodds, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: I'm not a young man anymore. I'm retired now. But I sometimes think that all the things in my life that have made it worth the living have been as a result of my connection to the dead gentleman.
quotation.source: Wesley Dodds, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: It's astonishing how much trouble one can get oneself into, if one works at it. And astonishing how much trouble one can get oneself out of, if one simply assumes that everything will, somehow or other, work out for the best.
quotation.source: Destruction, in SANDMAN #72, part three of "The Wake"

quotation.p: For a start, we never even noticed the Renaissance. The Renaissance was a load of bloody Italians poncing around claiming to be the golden age of the Greeks come around again. Nobody in England had even heard of the Renaissance until it had been over for centuries.
quotation.source: Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #73, epilogue to "The Wake"

quotation.p: "C'mon, Robbie. There weren't any black queens of England."
"Catherine of Aragon."
"She wasn't black. She was Spanish."

"There were a lot of Moors and Africans in Spain and Italy in the old days. Remember Othello? Trust me, if Catherine of Aragon had been in Alabama in the 1950s they'd have made her ride in the back of the bus."
quotation.source: Guenevere and Hob, in SANDMAN #73, epilogue to "The Wake"

quotation.p: "When I first met you I thought you were gay."
"Why? 'Cos I'm English?"
"Uh-uh. Because you seemed to know so many people who were dead."
"... That's not funny."
"No. It's not, is it?"
quotation.source: Guenevere and Hob, in SANDMAN #73, epilogue to "The Wake"

quotation.p: "They're all having a marvelous time. It's great."
"Well, thank you, little Miss Sunshine."
quotation.source: Death and Hob Gadling, in SANDMAN #73, epilogue to "The Wake"

quotation.p: Birds of a thousand colours danced in the sky when I was a boy. They brightened the day with their intricate songs. "We are who we choose to be," sang the goldfinch, when the sun was high. "I dream about dreams about dreams," sang the nightingale, under the pale moon.
quotation.source: Master Li, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: Old friend, in my mind only do I write you this letter, but it is a splendid letter, with perfect brushwork. Old hands do not shake or cramp when the letter is written on the air.
quotation.source: Master Li, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: "Father? I am your son. That is only a kitten. Why do you abandon me to chase after it?"
"When you were alive, you were all my joy. Now you are dead. I see you only in my dreams. And when I awake my pillow is wet with tears. The kitten is living, and it needs my help."
quotation.source: Reality shifts in the Soft Places, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: Why are you here, in this home of demons? Are you lost? Or are you also a demon? Forgive my bluntness, but I am an old man, and my flesh is sure to be stringy and lacking in taste: I doubt even a demon would relish it.
quotation.source: Master Li is frightened of Dream, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: I have no liking for prisons, Master Li. Sometimes I suspect that we build our traps ourselves, then we back into them, pretending amazement the while.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: "Lord -- what was it the barbarian said, as the riders vanished?"
"'Omnia mutantur, nihil interit.' 'Everything changes, but nothing is truly lost.' Fare you well, Master Li."
quotation.source: Master Li and Dream, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: But truth or no, still I believe in the correct manner, and correctness in behaviour is one of the cardinal virtues. I place the kitten in my sleeve once more. I have saved his life, as he saved mine, and am responsible for him. We cannot evade our responsibilities.
quotation.source: Master Li, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: I am banished to the grey waste at the end of the world, but I mourn myself no longer; I cherish the pain in my hand. I imagine the taste of the mulberries in the violet dusk. And tomorrow I shall arrive in the town of Wei.
quotation.source: Master Li, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: Only the phoenix arises and does not descend. And everything changes. And nothing is truly lost.
quotation.source: The true end of the series, in SANDMAN #74, "The Exile"

quotation.p: "Where does this one come from? Have you been raiding poor Holinshed again? Or does Plutarch bear the brunt of your depredations?"
"Bits of things, here and there, but it's mostly mine, for once."
quotation.source: Ben Jonson and William Shakespeare, in SANDMAN #75, "The Tempest"

quotation.p: Well, my own fine words notwithstanding, life is no play. We meet people once, and never see them again. There is no shape to events, no point at which we turn to the audience for their praise. No time at which we step behind the stage, to see the actors changing their wigs, and painting their faces, and muttering their lines.
quotation.source: William Shakespeare, in SANDMAN #75, "The Tempest"

quotation.p: "Nothing to fear? I thought I heard the beating of mighty wings, as in a nightmare that rode me when I was a boy..."
"You do. But have no fear of them."
quotation.source: Shakespeare and Dream, in SANDMAN #75, "The Tempest"

quotation.p: I watched my life as if it were happening to someone else. My son died, and I was hurt, but I watched my hurt, and relished it, a little, for now I could write a real death, a true loss.
quotation.source: William Shakespeare, in SANDMAN #75, "The Tempest"

quotation.p: The elephant swam to the island ahead of the Count's own skiff, and landed at exactly 3:00 PM.
quotation.source: From "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: At 3:02 PM a flock of snow-white doves rose into the air and flew across the island.
quotation.source: From "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "What are you doing?"
"Watching that gate. I'm waiting for the day that it opens."
"Well, why don't you just go around it?
"That wouldn't be fair. And what makes you think that I'd reach the same place if I went around it?"
quotation.source: Sergei and Death, from "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Each reveller, more resplendent than the last, was a symphony in blue, a confection in scarlet, a study in olive or vermilion or white, for the Count had decreed that the color black was forbidden on his island.
It carried overtones with which he was not entirely comfortable.
quotation.source: From "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Perhaps I would still be with Patricia, if, at each kiss, at every touch, I had not compared her to the woman on the island. Her eyes were not so dark and sparkling. Her smile was never so haunting.
quotation.source: Sergei, from "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "Where are we?"
"May the 23rd, 1751."
"That's a when, not a where."
"Here, it's a where."
quotation.source: Sergei and Death, from "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "My Lord! There are people dying!"
"Then tidy the bodies away, or make an artistic arrangement of them. Do not disturb me."
quotation.source: An unnamed servant and the Count, in "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: The people in the city seem paper thin in the mist. They believe they are dancing to the music of their lives... But I think, like the puppets, each of us is pulled upon invisible strings, until the night comes and we are put away.
quotation.source: Sergei, from "Death and Venice" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Most people want things like a candle-flame, flickering, shifting. You, on the other hand, want like a forest fire.
quotation.source: Desire, in "What I've Tasted of Desire" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: He's very, very young. He's called Sol. He makes me laugh, and he means well.
quotation.source: Mizar, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: I shall leave. Decide what you like at your parliament. It is all one to me. It won't make a lot of difference in the long run, will it? One by one, you will all come to me.
quotation.source: Death, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: I should go there. You know what they will be saying? Blah blah blah blah. That's what they are going to say. Blah blah blah blah blah.
quotation.source: Delight, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "I don't care if you are a dimension or not. If you're too small to be perceived, then I don't think you get to address the assembly."
"It's not a size thing. It's a matter of perception and respect."
quotation.source: Two delegates, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: The way I see it now, Faerie won't be a dimension so much as an aspiration.
quotation.source: A delegate, possibly Glory, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Truly, it would only be perfectly beautiful, a perfect piece of art, if one single life-form escaped. To remember, to mourn, to despair.
quotation.source: Despair, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "Did I hear you say you planned to have some of your planets inhabited?"
"Well, I'd certainly like it. Obviously, it's up to the planets themselves. None of them have woken yet."
"Yes. Their dreams are very lonely, and beautiful."
quotation.source: Dream and Sol, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: "Poor Dream. And what happened to her? To Killalla of the Glow?"

"She died, as they all die. They do not live long. But she made Sto-Oa happy, for a moment, and on her death he translated her into his center, to burn inside the heart of the star and comfort him through the long night."
"That's good. Poor Sto-Oa. Poor Killalla."
quotation.source: Sol and one of his planets, in "The Heart of a Star" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: When hope is past, she is there.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: She is on the other side of every mirror.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: She stands and waits, and in her posture the pain no longer tells you to live, and in her presence joy is unimaginable.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: She decides to make a list of the things that make her happy. She writes "plum-blossom" at the top of a piece of paper. Then she stares at the paper, unable to think of anything else. Eventually it begins to get dark.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Despair remembers. It is a peculiar, flat memory, in which things become bleak and bounded by the dark.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Her kiss is the deep ocean. Her kiss is not the deep ocean. Her kiss is the grey sky. Her kiss is a blind alley. Her kiss is her touch is her breath is her fingers is what remains after the laughing is over.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: A) If you can't be happy where you are, you can't be happy anywhere. Discuss, with examples from your own life.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: To be Despair. It is a portrait. Only close your eyes and feel.
quotation.source: From "Fifteen Portraits of Despair" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: The third eye. You spend years doing everything you can to open it and then the damn thing opens and your friends laugh at you when you tell them you can see their souls behind their eyes burning like rainbows.
Then the fourth eye opened and the fifth and the ones on the tips of his fingers and everything rainbows at the edges...
quotation.source: From "Going Inside" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: It's not from your future, you see. ... No... or maybe it is. But just a bit of one of them. I mean, there are so many of them. Like wiggly worms, millions and billions and squillions of wiggly worms, all wiggling in different ways to get to the same place.
quotation.source: Delirium, in "On The Peninsula" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: It's a nothing place. And my sister will take my brother's book and say "goodbye," and then it's all done. And that's it for this time round.
You don't believe me, but I don't mind. I don't always believe me either.
quotation.source: "On The Peninsula" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: You will spend time in the realm of each of his siblings -- you will dream, despair, desire, destroy, delight and otherwise, and, eventually, die -- but you were his from the very first page, and only he will read how your story comes out, a long time from now.
quotation.source: From "Endless Nights" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: It is all in his book. One day he will lay it down, when the book is done, and what comes after that is still unwritten.
quotation.source: From "Endless Nights" in ENDLESS NIGHTS

quotation.p: Quorian slept, petals closed in sleep, leaves and tendrils wrapped tight. Quorian dreamed of someone it had never encountered before. Someone with a white flower on a tall stem with dark, resplendent leaves.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #1

quotation.p: Once every month George Portcullis has a most peculiar and recurring dream. The dream contains a number of things that make it peculiar. For a start, when he is not dreaming, his name is most definitely not George Portcullis. He is certain of that.
Perhaps, when he is awake, he is a woman. Or a child.
Or a butterfly.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #1

quotation.p: Time goes in so many ways, Henrietta. It runs. Sometimes it even flies. But as for telling the time... sometimes what time tells us is for it alone to know. Thank you for your assistance.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: "Am I always like this?"
"Like what?"
"Self-satisfied. Irritating. Self-possessed, and unwilling to concede center stage to anyone but myself."
"I believe so, yes. In my experience."
quotation.source: Two aspects of Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: I was the Dream of the first created things: those that sleep in the space beneath space. They still sleep, in the space beyond space, in the cracks of the real. I am needed, and thus I remain.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: There are about four hundred billion galaxies in the Universe, Dream Lord. A star has gone mad, and the madness is spreading, like a cancer. Armies are massing from across the whole of creation, scenting battle.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: The woman sings once more. This time, the song she sings is joyous and filled with striving and desire, although it is still wordless. Above her, in the Universe, a star flares and goes out. She smiles. It is better than nothing.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: "Why are you still here?"
"I felt like it. I do not like being told what to do, not even by the Universe. I am the Dream of Cats, and I walk by myself."
quotation.source: Dream and the Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #2

quotation.p: The monks of Klaa know that the Universe is a distraction in the mind of God: as God meditates, seeking to clear its mind and achieve perfect enlightenment, ideas drift across the void. The monks of Klaa seek to remove all that is, molecule by molecule, in order to allow God to meditate undistracted, and to move on to the next state of being divine.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: "The path you are taking leads you, directly or indirectly, to your death."
"I believe that the same can be said of all paths, Lady. Of every track and way that any of us have walked since the Universe was young. But I appreciate your kindness."
quotation.source: One of the Ladies and Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: "What is it? What's that noise? Why is he making that noise? It scares me."
"He is laughing."
quotation.source: Hope and the Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: You're Prince of Stories. Tell me a story. It has to have you in it. And a princess. 'cause if there's a prince in a story there has to be a princess too.
quotation.source: Hope, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: This is just like all the stories, isn't it? A brave princess rescues a beautiful prince from a dungeon and from evil ogres.
quotation.source: Alianora, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: Oh! I like you, feisty thing. Just like the princes in the stories. Very pretty, but not terribly bright.
quotation.source: Alianora, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: I fashioned gates from their horns. I took the bones of the one who had hurt me, and I fashioned them into a helm, to remind myself always of my defeat: to wear into battle, and into danger.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #3

quotation.p: Before the beginning was the night. And the night was without boundaries and the night was without end. In the beginning was time. The relentless beat in which things could happen, in which everything could become, dust could coalesce, matter could exist.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: I am bored. I am going to close my eyes and ponder the dreams of nebulae. Call me -- gently -- when this is all done, human child.
quotation.source: The Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: I had never killed, not then. I had ended no innocent lives. I thought myself too wise, too noble, too gentle to murder. And duty... it was something I believed in, but still, it was just a word.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: "You know you can kill, my brother, when the Dreaming is endangered. And it has never been more endangered than now. How much longer will you wait? Until the stars go mad? The nebulae? The Universe?"
"It is wrong. I was not made to kill innocents."
"Everybody kills, little brother. They even kill their dreams. And you have waited too long."
quotation.source: Death and Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: If we kill you, another aspect of yourself will take your place. That is what I learned at the congress at the dawn of time. So we will not kill you, dream king. We will simply render you unavailable. Inside the event horizon of a dark star, nothing ever gets out. No light, no information. And definitely no dreams. Goodnight.
quotation.source: Fomalhaut, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #4

quotation.p: I am trapped inside a black hole. I am removed from the worlds. I reach out with my mind and I touch nothing and no one: no dreaming minds, no pictures, no emotions, no thought, no life... Time is dissolved in the darkness. I am a child of Time and Night, and this place will prove my end.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #5

quotation.p: I was expelled from the universe, by stars caught up with rhetoric and infection.
quotation.source: Dream, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #5

quotation.p: "What is this place?"
"This is the afterlife of your people, only permitted to those who died before adulthood."
"Then how did you get here?"
"Have you ever tried to keep a cat out of anywhere it wanted to be?"
quotation.source: Hope and the Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #5

quotation.p: In the grand dance of creation and destruction, of entropy and irony, the worlds are ending and she is there for all of them.
quotation.source: From SANDMAN: OVERTURE #6

quotation.p: I made them toast with piggables on it. Piggables is like pigs and also it is like vegetables.
quotation.source: Delirium, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #6

quotation.p: "Just want to. Just know you are going to. He will do the rest. Want to. Want."
"Yes."
quotation.source: Hope and the Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #6

quotation.p: We have only the slightest chance, but that is enough. ... Because we cannot do this alone. Yes. Because once the world belonged to the cats. Because you allowed it to change. Because it is the nature of Dreams, and only of Dreams, to define Reality. Destiny is bound to existence. Death is limited by what she will or will not accept.
quotation.source: The Dream of Cats, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #6

quotation.p: Dreams might be done, but so would Desire: mine is the force that keeps bacteria and galaxies together. Lust and wanting and all the things that drive them, craving, needing... the breath of Desire.
quotation.source: Desire, in SANDMAN: OVERTURE #6
